ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the basic principles of music theory through Western and non-Western notation/scale systems. We worked through key interval concepts through vocalization and other hands-on techniques/practices.
I developed a basic knowledge of musical concepts such as pitch and rhythm, as well as more specialized knowledge, such as the foundations of South Indian musical education.
I learned basic concepts of how to read music and music theory.
I learned the basics of music theory, especially solfege, intervals, notation, and the circle of fifths. I also learned some aspects of South Indian music.
I learned music transcription.
A better understanding of the building blocks of music and notation
how to read music, how to count musical cycles, harmonies, etc

I got a very basic foundation from which to begin understanding Western music theory. I have an okay understanding of pitch and time, and how they're notated basically. I also learned a bit about scales and intervals in Carnatic music.

We spent most of the course learning about the Carnatic music system. In-class time was mostly spent learning about intervals and practicing singing scales. From the Western music system, we learned about key signatures, notating rhythm, the names for different-sized intervals, and the circle of thirds and fifths, and got a bit of practice with transcription

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: In class, we were introduced to a plethora of topics and figured out the principles of music theory through singing in practice. In section, we clarified the content we practiced in class and discussed assignments. As the course structure is still being worked out, we went through different forms of mini-quizzes and assignments to see what fit our class best. Versatility of content and practice was wonderful but would not be conducive to students seeking a rigid structure in their course.
This course was very good, and I know that the professor is committed to making it even better!

A strength of this course is how it starts from scratch to introduce the concept of music so those with no musical experience can understand the class. A weakness is how fast some of the concepts were taught such as rhythm.
I loved how we grounded a lot of our coursework in Carnatic music, that was really interesting

This was a new course, so some elements were still being fleshed out. As an example, I didnt find the notation labs that helpful. That said, the focus on singing made the course very engaging, and I actually found the final project fun. It was always a course I looked forward to, and it felt like it catered to students with a wide range of musical training, including none at all.
loved singing <3

I think it would be more realistic to have two separate courses on music theory for those with and without some previous study of music, since I felt like that gap was never really bridged fully.  The organization of the course wasn't the strongest, but I thought the assignments we did have were genuinely helpful to my learning.

The class helped me a lot with aural skills/my ability to recognize the difference between half and whole steps, a perfect fifth, etc. Though I was already familiar with MuseScore and transcribing music, this course also strengthened my skills in that area and introduced me to new tools like Sonic Visualizer which aided me even further with transcription. Class sessions were very engaging and fun, especially when we got to sight-sing.

Though I appreciated the course being centered around the Carnatic music system and learning a different way to view music outside the Western system, I would have also enjoyed learning some of the concepts in more traditional music theory courses, especially chords and harmony.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would highly recommend! Professor Quinn is a kind human willing to work with you to ensure your learning AND mental health are prioritized. Even if you have previous musical experience, he makes sure that the content is tailored to a wide range of previous skill sets.
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student like me, who doesn't have a background in music theory but is interested in learning.
Yes, I think it was a great course to take and was a nice way to learn about music and get a college credit.
fun
Absolutely! Its fun, you get to sing, and its a gateway to more music courses at Yale
Yes
Yes! Fun and a good balance for other courses
yes, prof Quinn is amazing!

Maybe not, at least until the organization of the course is cemented. It's being workshopped right now, and so the course isn't as conducive to learning as it could be, and I did feel like I missed out on learning quite a few important musical concepts.
